instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B (defective <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) now brain dead
threads.message:
This one is unlike any I have ever seen.

Initial problem.  "no post" but power rails measured normal.   My 3V3 and 5V rails that <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is responsible for were good!  However the machine did pull about 200mA too much power.  
Thermal imaging showed <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was getting too hot.   I could not find any shorts around this IC so I decided to replace it even though I was shaking my head how.   Over heating of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> was now fixed and power rails as before were still good but the board was not booting.

Presently all rails are up and we have S0 good.  
CPU loads bios and starts RAM activity.  
Board does not cycle three times like normal and never enables the screen.

We are currently brain dead.  This is a very old board and I am going to total it.  but OMG what the hell is this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B (defective <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) now brain dead
threads.message: When you get all power rails, including VCORE, new BIOS is an option to try.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B (defective <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) now brain dead
threads.message: Did that first thing.. No help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B (defective <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>) now brain dead
threads.message:
Did you check for USB activity?
Try heating BGA chips with good flux; in case of accumulated crap between balls.
